metadata.case_name: Appellants v. State of West Bengal

facts.text: Five appellants: four employees of Indian Iron Steel Co., Ltd., fifth an outsider.

Appellants convicted by Magistrate of Asansol under s. 27 of Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, for instigating and inciting others to take part in illegal strike; sentenced to simple imprisonment for three months.
Conviction confirmed by Additional Sessions Judge, Asansol, in Criminal Appeal No. 125 of 1955 on July 21, 1955.
Revision petition dismissed by Calcutta High Court on July 4, 1956, in Criminal Revision No. 1005 of 1955.
Appeal to Supreme Court by special leave.
Company owns factory at Burnpur near Asansol, Sheet Mill declared public utility service.

Slow-down strike in Hot Mill section of Sheet Mill; company issued charge-sheets to workers including four appellants for slow-down, instigating others, other misconduct; after enquiry, dismissed four appellants.
On dismissal, slow-down strike gained strength.

Company notice dated April 8, 1953, to Hot Mill Sheet Mill workers: unless record willingness to operate plant to normal capacity by April 10, 2 p.m., considered no longer employed; company will recruit other labour.
40 Hot Mill workers recorded willingness; about 300 did not respond.
On April 11, 1953, entire Sheet Mill workers (about 1300) went on sit-down strike lasting till April 20, 1953.

Company notice dated April 25, 1953: in accordance with April 8 notice, considered no longer employed after April 10, 2 p.m., as no willingness recorded; formal discharge kept pending; final notice, if no willingness by 11 a.m. April 28, name removed from rolls, discharge fully effective.
On April 27, 1953, entire factory workers except essential services went on strike lasting 22 hours.
Company filed complaint under s. 27 on May 19, 1953, with government sanction on May 2, 1953.
Appellants did not challenge finding that strikes took place and they instigated them.
Labour Minister of West Bengal intervened; on April 21, 1953, suggested terms: discharged Hot Mill workers report for duty and record willingness, government recommends reinstatement.
No evidence that prior to 2 p.m. April 10, 1953, any employee prevented from attending duty.

legal_issues.text: Whether the strikes of April 11-20, 1953, and April 27, 1953, were illegal under s. 24(1) of the Industrial Disputes Act, 1947, or justified as consequence of illegal lock-out under s. 24(3).
Whether company notices dated April 8 and 25, 1953, constituted a lock-out or a discharge of workers.
Whether discharge of employees amounts to a lock-out within s. 2(1) definition.
Validity of sanction under s. 34(1) for complaint under s. 27.

petitioner_arguments.text: Strikes not illegal under s. 24(3) as in consequence of illegal lock-out of 300 Hot Mill workers by notices of April 8 and 25.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s. 24(3), s. 22, s. 2(1) Industrial Disputes Act

petitioner_arguments.text: Notices use same words as definition of lock-out in s. 2(1).
Notices did not effect discharge till April 28, 1953; meantime lock-out as services not terminated but not allowed duties.
Even if discharge, it is lock-out as definition covers refusal to continue to employ.
Sanction invalid as granted without reference to facts constituting offence.

respondent_arguments.text: Strikes illegal under s. 24(1) as commenced in contravention of s. 22; no lock-out, notices effected discharge.

court_reasoning.text: Notices of April 8 and 25 effected discharge on April 10, 1953, not lock-out; April 8 notice plainly meant cessation of employment on failure to comply; April 25 confirmed considered no longer employed from April 10, formal discharge (name removal) pending.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Workers ceased to be in employment on April 10; no other meaning possible.

court_reasoning.text: Discharge not lock-out under s. 2(1); words differ ('considered no longer employed' vs 'refusal to continue to employ'); context shows discharge severs employment relation, unlike lock-out.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Lock-out counterpart to strike, does not contemplate severance of employer-employee relation.

court_reasoning.text: Interpreting discharge as lock-out conflicts with Act's scheme: ss. 22,23 prohibit lock-outs without notice/ during conciliation; would prevent immediate discharge for misconduct; conflicts with s. 33; later amendments (s. 2(oo), 25F) distinguish retrenchment/discharge from lock-out.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Absurd results if discharge = lock-out; Presidency Jute Mills followed.

court_reasoning.text: Strikes illegal under s. 24(1) contravening s. 22; no illegal lock-out, so s. 24(3) inapplicable; instigation offence under s. 27.
Sanction valid; evidence shows all facts placed before authority, even if not on face.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Judicial Committee in Gokalchand allows proof by evidence.

holdings.text: Company notices effected discharge, not lock-out.
Discharge of employees does not amount to lock-out under s. 2(1) of Industrial Disputes Act.
Strikes illegal under s. 24(1); conviction under s. 27 upheld.

precedents_cited.case_name: Presidency Jute Mills Co. Ltd. v. Presidency Jute Mills Co. Employees Union
precedents_cited.relevance: Discharge not lock-out; definition means refusal to allow work without termination of service.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gokalchand Dwarkadas Morarka v. The King
precedents_cited.relevance: Sanction valid if facts placed before authority, proved by evidence even if not on face.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines lock-out (excludes discharge); regulates strikes/lock-outs in public utility services; prohibits illegal strikes/lock-outs; offence for instigation; sanction required; distinguishes retrenchment/discharge.

outcome.summary: Appeal fails; convictions under s. 27 upheld as strikes illegal, no lock-out by company; sentence modified to period already served plus fine of Rs. 100, or 15 days simple imprisonment in default, for each appellant.

key_quotes.text: "lock-out means the refusal by an employer to continue to employ any number of persons employed by him."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Definition from s. 2(1); distinguishes from discharge.

key_quotes.text: "The notice of April 8 clearly stated that unless the workers notified their willingness... by 2 p.m. on April 10, they would be considered to be no longer in the employment of the Company."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Interprets notice as effecting discharge on April 10.

key_quotes.text: "A strike is a weapon of the workers while a lock-out that of the employer. A strike does not, of course, contemplate the severance of the relation of employer and employed."
key_quotes.speaker: court
